headline.main: Accidentally in the Path of Package Bomber, 23 Lives Are Indelibly Changed

results.snippet: Shrapnel from a homemade bomb tore through Hugh Campbell Scrutton's heart in a windswept parking lot here in 1985, and the computer store owner cried for God's help as he died beside a Dumpster.   Earlier that year, a similar explosion at the...
results.lead_paragraph: Shrapnel from a homemade bomb tore through Hugh Campbell Scrutton's heart in a windswept parking lot here in 1985, and the computer store owner cried for God's help as he died beside a Dumpster. Earlier that year, a similar explosion at the University of California at Berkeley blew the fingers off Capt. John E. Hauser's right hand, ending the flying career of the ambitious young Air Force pilot and engineering student and shattering his dream of becoming an astronaut.

headline.main: Exploring the Sorcery of the Theater

results.snippet: ON a recent Sunday the David Black gallery in Kent -- where Peoplescapes (24 paintings by David Black) and Landscapes (26 paintings by David Black) were on exhibit -- was hopping. And displayed in the window of the town's bookstore was "The Magic...
results.lead_paragraph: ON a recent Sunday the David Black gallery in Kent -- where Peoplescapes (24 paintings by David Black) and Landscapes (26 paintings by David Black) were on exhibit -- was hopping. And displayed in the window of the town's bookstore was "The Magic of Theater" (18 conversations with 33 actors, conducted by David Black). "I want to become a star," said a 9-year-old browser named Kirsten to Mr. Black when he showed up for the book signing. Mr. Black may not be able to tell Kirsten, whose mother bought a signed copy, exactly how to become a star, but the ones quoted in the book might offer some inspiration along the way. William Hurt, for one, talks of theater as a communal experience of strangers bravely solving their humanity together.
